awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:  Linking landslide and windstorm exposure to regional carbon stocks and fluxes in the largest US forest carbon reservoir, southeast Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
Landslides are important factors in the global carbon cycle as well as a significant risk to human life around the world. This project focuses on better understanding the geophysics of landslides in forested areas, specifically how they move soils and woody debris. Understanding the complex mechanics of these debris flows is essential to determining the relationship between landslides and carbon stocks in forested systems worldwide. By coupling with a regional wind exposure model, this work will also create a new way of visualizing hazard/risk to communities in steep terrain, relevant to many small towns in the US and abroad. Explicit coordination with those communities is planned.

This study will address a fundamental question in disturbance ecology: How much disturbance maximizes carbon on a landscape, and where is that carbon located? This is globally relevant, as disturbances are projected to increase as a result of climate warming in most systems. Second, it will incorporate woody debris into mechanical landslide models, which will fundamentally advance our geological understanding of this process. Extensive fieldwork will be coupled with physics-based numerical modeling to synthesize a full scientific understanding of how disturbances influence the landscape and ecosystem with respect to carbon cycling.

This award is cofunded by the Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics Program, the Prediction of and Resilience against Extreme Events Program, and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is the primary driver of human-caused climate change. Trees take up carbon dioxide and turn it into biomass (trees and other plants), and send some of it into soils, where it is sequestered over long time scales. Thus, forests act as carbon ?sinks,? and old growth temperate rainforests such as those in southeast Alaska are particularly effective agents of carbon sequestration. But the mechanisms governing spatial heterogeneity in carbon stocks on the landscape are not well understood beyond simple first-order factors like elevation and slope (which controls drainage). 

Basic theory suggests that in old growth, rarely disturbed ecosystems, there is a tendency towards retrogression, where ecosystems lose biomass over long time periods. The high biomass, important carbon storehouses of southeast Alaska therefore represent a unique opportunity. First, they are incredibly important from a carbon standpoint, and second, we can explore the role of disturbances in driving that carbon storehouse. The rainforests are generally very low disturbance frequency, but do have two infrequent regimes - landslides and wind.  Both are topographically controlled, and so modelable. Our project examined the role of landslides and wind storms in the carbon balance of the forests to better understand the carbon budget in these important ecosystems. We found that while landslides can be destructive by removing and mobilizing trees and soils, they also promote forest productivity. That is, where landslides occur, more carbon ends up being stored in the forest. Landslides also promote the transport of carbon to streams, which can send the carbon out to the ocean for burial, helping to yield a net drawdown of atmospheric carbon dioxide. This project resulted in the first high resolution spatial map of carbon as well as the first estimate of carbon flux from terrestrial systems via landslides, an important but never before quantified contribution to total C fluxes. Wind, on the other hand, was not important in the study area in explaining spatial carbon distribution. 

Considerable analytical effort was also targeted at understanding uncertainty in carbon accounting methods in the region - we found it to be quite high, and uncertainty that comes from existing carbon accounting schemes is substantial and must be better resolved for reliable, large scale carbon accounting methods using traditional methods. 

Our project involved field work and lab work that trained several graduate students, undergraduate students, and classes and trainings to local middle and high school students. It also provided educational outreach to the citizens of the city of Sitka, which has suffered human tragedy from landslides in the recent past. Two Masters students were trained in this project (one of which now enrolled as a PhD student at Cornell).  The project involved multiple educational seminars and classroom work in Sitka over the course of the grant (which spanned the covid shutdown) and a one month community engagement effort with the Sitka Sound Science Center, where one PI stayed in Sitka for continual community engagement in the project.

It also produced four peer reviewed publications to date, with one in review and additional anticipated; a successful follow-up NSF proposal to Buma focused on using the knowledge here to further carbon modeling methods and link with carbon credit firms to assess the potential for high quality credits (stable, repeatable, transparent, additional), and many presentations.
